item.title: "Our other boy" by John Lam
item.description: We're using a Logitech notebook mouse as well. The full-sized mice are just too large right now. We also remapped the right button to the left. Interestingly enough, he uses his thumb to click the mouse. I guess he's training himself for SMS text messaging already!

item.title: "Our other boy" by Anson Tsao
item.description: I find the Microsoft Wireless notebook mouse just about the right size for little hands, and using AutoHotKey to map right to left mouse button really helped.

item.title: "Ruby in the real world" by John Lam
item.description: I've been working on the bridge on and off all week. I have constructor overloading, method overloading, and indexer support baked in. Next up is wrapping up properties, fields and events. That should make for a usable release. If I have enough cycles - that should ship towards end of next week.

item.title: "Ruby in the real world" by Justin
item.description:
Speaking of the .NET-CLR bridge, any updates available? I imagine you are busy with the new addition to the family so I'm not too hopeful - but I'm still excited about it!

In the future, could you provide a DLL with the download? I don't have VS2005 and thus can't compile the DLL for myself ...

item.title: "Ruby in the real world" by Sorin
"Ruby in the real world" by John Lam
item.description:
I wouldn't go so far as to claim that web sites are trivial. I personally feel that web applications are among the most complicated applications that developers have to tackle.

And besides, why all the buzz about Rails if you could just as easily use CGI and C? Are all of those Java developers smoking crack?

item.title: "Ruby in the real world" by Sam Gentile
item.description:
Thanks for responding John. I am not interested in searching Google for Ruby on Rails for just web sites. Thats easy stuff as CGI and C could be used. Web sites are trivial.

I am more interested in "real world" apps like the one you mentioned for your customer. Thats what my question was about.
